title: Tory plot to oust Commons Speaker John Bercow after Donald Trump ban has flopped
text:
Tory plot to oust Commons Speaker John Bercow after Donald Trump ban has flopped Just five MPs backed a no confidence motion in John Bercow over his “unilateral” decision to ban Donald Trump from speaking in Parliament Share Comments By Ben Glaze 16:34, 21 FEB 2017 Updated 16:44, 21 FEB 2017 News The plot to oust John Bercow has failed (Photo: PA) politics A Tory plot to oust Commons Speaker John Bercow flopped after just five MPs backed a no confidence motion.
Mr Bercow faced down Conservative demands for an apology following his “unilateral” decision to ban Donald Trump from speaking in Parliament .
The move was welcomed by Opposition MPs but triggered fury among Tory backbenchers, and reignited calls for Mr Bercow to quit.
But he quelled the latest row and saw off the latest attempt to topple him.
Just five MPs backed a no confidence motion targeted at the Speaker, tabled after he declared he would refuse permission for Mr Trump to speak in Westminster Hall during his state visit later this year.
Read More Thousands write to John Bercow backing ban on Donald Trump speaking in parliament John Bercow has banned Donald Trump from Parliament (Photo: REUTERS) Mr Bercow issued the ruling without consulting his counterpart in the Lords - which later prompted him to apologise to his opposite number in the Upper House.
Tory Andrew Bridgen called for the Speaker to apologise to the Commons yesterday, telling him: “You quite rightly apologised to the Lord Speaker for unilaterally seeking to ban the president of the United States from Westminster Hall.
“It was quite right to do that. When can we expect an apology in this chamber?”
 this video again Video will play in Donald Trump BANNED from speaking in Parliament But defiant Mr Bercow insisted the matter has been dealt with adding: “We shall leave it there.”
Conservative former minister James Duddridge, who tabled the no confidence motion, admitted it had attracted “underwhelming support”.
But he insisted the issue was “unresolved” and should be debated and voted on.
